review_title: Great place to start a career but it does not value retention and development
job_title: Senior Programmer Manager in London, England
pros:
1. Exposure to incredibly rewarding work across the globe
2. Opportunity to make a real difference
3. Articulates strong values especially when it comes to Equality, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI)
cons:
1. Does not live by its values, promotions and opportunities are based on who you know in the organisation and your ability to network rather than own merit. New employees over-valued compared to long-standing employees who hold institutional knowledge, constant change of senior leadership (country level) who change direction every 3-4 years is wasteful and depletes energy. 

2. Overall, not enough transferable skills as you're developing skills and experience to run a very unique business model and if you're made redundant it's hard to find similar jobs. 

3. There is no process for senior managers to whistleblow on mental health issues - Covid-19 was incredibly stressful, a lot of senior managers kept the stress to themselves for fear of being seen as weak or being passed for promotions and/or other opportunities. The organisation overvalued success stories so it made it toxic as the real pressures on the ground became invisible.

review_title: Uninspiring and away from the action
pros: Objectively I know the British Council does some important, inspirational work around the world and has made a positive difference to many people's lives. It is a well respected organisation in many countries.
cons: The London office, and my team, is uninspiring. I feel very far removed from the actual important work the British Council does around the world. Processes are slow and bureaucratic, there's little innovation, and it seems like it's just a core group of people who get to be involved in any of the more exciting, international opportunities. There is no career progression, there have been no pay increases in the more than two years I've been there, and I don't feel like I'm contributing to a greater cause.

review_title: Noble ambitions brought down by poor management and awful change policies
pros:
The goal of the British Council is an admirable one: to build connections between countries for our collective benefit. This doesn't always manifest itself properly in every project, but the overarching purpose of the organisation usually results in positive change.

The work life balance is generally very good, with flexi time and plenty of annual leave. I have never had issues getting desired time off for holidays, medical appointments, etc. 

The civil service Alpha pension scheme is excellent.

Plenty of high profile projects with other departments.
cons:
The endless 'transformation' changes that senior management push every few years are an utter waste of time and resource that add nothing of value to the organisation. Each time it happens the result isn't a more efficient structure, but severe disruption, frustration and stress that pushes the most talented and desirable employees to leave the company for better opportunities elsewhere (HR make very little effort to retain them). 

This brain drain combines with the fact that it is almost impossible to fire permanent employees no matter how awful they are, meaning that building long term success is all but impossible. There's great individuals that work here, but very few great teams. 

The organisation is disjointed across countries, with different regions operating within silos. Even within single countries, teams often work in isolation from one another which results in a lot of redundant work and poor communication.

The organisation tackles diversity in misguided ways. Representation often feels like classic civil service tokenism rather than anything meaningful, with EDI discourse mostly being done by middle-class white women with degrees. Upper management is slowly recognising the issue, but little actual change so far.

review_title: Avoid unless your priority is work-life balance.
pros:
Pleasant office environment in a central location.
Subsided canteen.
Opportunities to travel widely.
Interesting organisation.
Easy to get away with not coming into the office very much at all and not doing any work.  Plenty of people in my team I didn't see week to week and appeared to do next to no work.  I can not exaggerate enough the number of cushy jobs.  Personally, I don't really see this as a pro.
cons:
Insecure FTC
Poor management
Poor leadership.
Lots of people who have worked there for years and years who are under-qualified for technical jobs they are in.
Complete lack of accountability for failure and waste.
Line managed by day rate contractors.  I had 6 line managers in under 2 years as they all left or were fired.
Poorly run projects.
Lack of consideration that people need job security - I would advise against taking a FTC there.  They do not respect that you need notice and will not let you know if they aren't going to renew.
No career progression.  People progress based on being friends with the right people not on talent.  Management isn't qualified enough themselves to recognise talent.
Extremely hierarchical in a way which doesn't compare to any organisation I have been a part of.  Very old fashioned.  Senior management really appear to believe they are better than the people they manage!
They do not like people below them giving their opinions.  Only work here if you're prepared to keep your experience & skills to yourself!
Not good if you are trying to advance your career.

job_title: Estate and Administrative Officer in London, England
pros:
-	Support the day to day delivery of Maintenance, Security, and Health and Safety services by providing a proactive support and advice on all aspects of Security and Health and Safety in the workplace to all users of British Council premises. 
-	Support the British Council in managing the maintenance of rented property used by UK staff to a high standard by providing an efficient and cost effective service to the occupiers with a strong focus on customer service
-	Support the organisation of office moves with minimal disruption to normal works. 
-	Support the delivery of events by implementing agreed tasks for H&S and Security
-	Support the management of procurements and fixed Assists & inventory records.
-	Overall Management of the mailroom services ( including courier and stationery contracts, photocopying contract).
-	Manage 13 staff members, ensuring outputs are achieved and targets and standards met.
-	Manage all stages in 2 projects in the last 3 years
cons:
-	SAP responsibility at British Council
-	Sales orders are created in line with the corporate policy
-	Income is recorded promptly in the system as received in line with the corporate policy
-	POs are created in line with the corporate policy
-	POs are good receipted once goods/services have been delivered
-	POs are cleared when not required
-	Creditors are paid on time
-	Vendors are created promptly and creation process is followed up with the Hub to ensure vendors are created within 3 working days.
-	Vendors are created in line with policy and Creation forms are checked for accuracy.

pros: Leave policy, working with talent, flexible working, many areas to work in/across
cons: Lots of policies, a lot to navigate.

pros: The work I do is interesting and varied. There are opportunities to get involved in lots of different projects and types of work, including international travel. The organisations objectives and values are focused on making a positive difference in the world. The atmosphere in all the British Council offices I have visited in the UK and abroad was relaxed, friendly and fun. Working in partnership with other organisations also allows you to have experience outside the British Council ‘bubble’. Flexible working helps to facilitate a comfortable work/life balance.
cons: The wages are low compared to an equivalent position in the private sector. The pace of change is extremely slow in the organisation. Working through different levels of internal bureaucracy can been challenging and frustrating. At times the work-load means you are working at maximum capacity to deliver what you need to. Opportunities to advance to a more senior position can be limited.

review_title: Depends who you are and where you work
pros:
If you're a UK appointed working overseas benefits are pretty good
Some pretty flexible and sympathetic managers
cons:
There is a lot of favouritism, getting on is as much about playing the game and sucking up as it is about being good at your job
A lot of senior people at the centre and in the regions lack much needed leadership skills
There's a lot of change at the moment managed by people who are not particularly qualified 
Poor internal communications
Very top down, the thoughts and opinions of UK appointed staff in many countries are valued more than local/national staff who have been employed for numerous years
An increasingly fearful organisation that lacks confidence in the face of e.g. FCO and DIT colleagues. 
Very short-termist at the moment

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Manchester, England
pros:
Wonderful staff around the world who genuinely care about the business. Wonderful team in Manchester. 
Good holiday (32 days). Flexible working.
cons: Lack of strategy/vision/direction from global leadership , too heavy a focus on savings through headcount, not enough focus on how to better ourselves as an organisation.

review_title: Great people and a great organisation
pros: Diverse areas of work and lots of opportunities to try out different roles. There are three broad areas of work: English and Exams, Education and Society and Arts and Culture.
cons: The industry is challenging at the moment so opportunities for growth are limited. Bottlenecks in decision making and lack of information sharing at corporate level makes it very difficult to work. Technology and tools are cumbersome so collabaorative working is very difficult.

review_title: Lovely Company To Work For, Horrible Job
job_title: Customer Service Advisor in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Amazing colleagues! Literally the most lovely people you could ever wish to meet.
cons: The Customer Service role is pretty awful (as probably most Customer Service jobs are). The role entails responding to IELTS student enquiries, as well as Teachers arranging List of Travellers visas. Customers contact the British Council by phone and email and it really is a non-stop barrage of abuse (surprisingly, teachers are one the worst offenders). If you are thick-skinned and don't mind being shouted at all day, then this is the job for you. The plus side is, everyone who works there is generally lovely and they will make you feel very welcome. The people make the role bearable.

review_title: Be careful what you wish for
pros: Exposure to numerous programmes on international level
cons:
- The exposure is merely administrative.
- Poor HR practices
- Everyone who succeeded in the 3 year graduate programme left after the very first year
- Awful management in general
- No career progression
- Bonus pay system is a complete scham
- High employee turnover
- Misrepresentation of advertised roles (the work has nothing in common with the job profile or job title). A project coordinator is there to send out emails only to customers.
- Lack of decision-making procedures / managers avoid taking resposibility for anything

pros: Opportunities for career progression and professional development, travel (for some), you can have a good work-life balance (but you have to make it happen yourself), modern IT, good pension, interesting work in a not for profit organisation, good equal opps.
cons: The BC has offices in over 100 countries and like any big organisation it struggles with bureaucracy. Cuts to budgets and pressure of work leads some people to work much longer hours than they are paid for. Change is constant. It used to be the case that the organisation was more prepared to listen to expensive external consultants rather than its own staff (with often more experience.)

review_title: The British Council is a great place and I enjoyed working with a diverse group of people on a range on projects
pros:
The people
The reputation
The work/life balance

The British Council is a great place to work with a fantastic history. With flexi-time, generous annual leave packages and a range of opportunities for international travel, I would not hesitate to recommend it to people as a place of work.
cons: Lack of opportunity for involvement in the strategic direction of the organisation and somethimes a distance between senior management and staff.

review_title: A place where politics are played.
pros:
Flexible working
Bonus
Diversity
Opportunity to travel
Opportunity to meet interesting and smart people
cons:
Very Political
Brilliant people leave as they are not appreciated
Lots of people in higher bands that do 0 work but are good playing politic games

job_title: Head of Department in London, England
pros:
Culturally diverse, has good values and actually follows them.
You work in a job where you know you are making the world a better place and can look at yourself in the mirror in the morning.
Good opportunities if you want to travel or build a career in cultural relations. Good chance to move sideways and develop
cons: Some senior managers need an MBA. Marketing is disorganised and weak because of lack of commercial focus and experience by staff

review_title: Global organisation with great work ethics
pros: BC is present in 130+ countries which give a fantastic opportunity to get involved in truly global products and make a positive impact on local communities. Very collaborative environment, knowledge sharing culture and professional colleagues, make it a great experience of achieving success together.
cons: Salaries and competence of staff are not reflective their qualifications/workload.  Onboarding process may be lengthy and a bit too rigorous at times.

pros: The British Council has a long history (since 1934!) in specialising in international educational and cultural opportunities in over 110 countries worldwide. I belong to a team of over 5,000 colleagues all working for the above common goals. Very proud to work for them for very proud to connect millions of people with the United Kingdom through programmes and services in the English language, the Arts, Education and Society.
cons: Nothing negative - except the lack of pay rises in the public sector for so many years.

pros: I did one year contract at the British Council and enjoyed every minute of it. The people are great, they are friendly and highly motivated and enthusiastic. The management listen to you and are happy to take onboard ideas for improvement.
cons: Not always easy to get the right people together when you need them for quick decision making, as the heads of departments travel globally frequently and not always accessible directly.

pros:
The British Council does some very inspirational work across the world
The breadth of programmes and offer is astounding
People actually believe they are changing the world
Pension scheme is very good
cons:
Almost impossible to get any work done due to bureaucracy
Very hierarchical
Poor communication
Zero motivation from all staff
The guy at the top of organisation only gets in touch about cakes on birthdays

pros: Plenty of benefits as an employee. Such as working from home where all the equipment is supplied and fitted. Flexible hours. Great people to work with and for.
cons: Sometimes the customers can get a bit hard to deal with but that is like anywhere you go you will get complaints from customers but the quality and knowledge you provide overcomes it.

pros: Fantastic organisation delivering hope to  international relations and educational opportunities - most of the staff are great, all around the world. Work life balance.
cons: Internal management is a bit of a shambles - doesnt really follow its own 'values', however the team ethic is good. Pay! Moving to Stratford from SW1.

pros: Working with excellent colleagues on a range of interesting projects is the main thing that keeps me here.  There is the opportunity for international travel if you are suitably qualified.
cons: Low salary and no possibility for pay rise for internal staff.  The organisation is also very siloed and you can get pigeon holed rvery easily.

pros: Genuinely nice people, great work life balance
cons: Senior Management are really average. Culturally there is a 'can't do attitude' and a resistance to change and different ways of thinking. Senior Management often take the easy option rather than right option. There is an ongoing cycle of hefty redundancies followed by massive recruitment. I wasn't surprised to hear of their ongoing financial difficulties.

job_title: Help Desk Analyst in London, England
pros:
People excellent to work with
Good opportunities in the future likely for permanent staff (though I was only a contractor)
Using leading edge technology
Took me back after travelling for several months, big plus.
cons:
I was only contracting, going permanent was not a easy option.
Money offered was slightly lower than the market rate

.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros: Good work-life balance in my experience. Good opportunities for lateral movements.Overall a fairly relaxed place to work.
cons: Low salaries in most cases, and even compared to other British Council offices in other parts of the world; public service rigidities. Very little investment in staff - marketable training is almost non-existent. Big danger you'll be branded as public sector if you spend any significant amount of time here.

pros: Handing in my notice and leaving the office at 5pm
cons: Far too many to list here. Managers are incompetent, racist undertones, discriminate, particularly HR. Nepotism abound. Favouritism, brown nosing. Spending far too much of the tax payers money on rubbish. Such as the extensive art collection they own, priced over £50 million. The horse sculpture outside the premises cost £500k alone. Of our money! What a joke.   The list is endless.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: Some of the people working for the British Council are amazing. You get staff from all over the world which helps you develop as a person and get to learn about different cultures as well as knowing you are making a difference in what you work on.
cons: Management has clearly changed views are not the same as they were a couple of years ago.

review_title: It's great working somewhere that does good
pros: The incredible diversity of its staff, locations, work. Feeling proud about everything we do throughout the world. Flexible working policy is good. Generous holiday entitlement
cons: Career development can be tricky if not in certain roles. Civil service so pay is below average- especially for London. Red-tape can get tiring

review_title: I had a long and good career here
pros: International ,  great colleagues, interesting work, opportunities for travel and development
cons: Bureaucratic, self-absorbed, can be difficult to get in and progression often slow, especially if you are unable to take up overseas posts.

pros: The people who work here are like minded and fantastic, striving to help make the world a better place through international collaboration and engagement. Very supportive of flexible working and career progression opportunities.
cons: There's a lot of office politics and corporate bureaucracy to put up with. The bonus pay by performance process is unfair and outdated and makes it hard to progress.

pros:
- Interesting environment and colleagues]
- Possibility to work overseas 
- Good work/life balance (holiday, flexible working)
- Great maternity cover
cons:
- Salaries very low (even for charity sector
- Bureaucratic and unclear decision making processes
- Difficult to progress to senior management
- Non ending restructure programmes

pros:
Great opportunity to travel and build a global network
Strong on diversity in the workplace
Meet fabulous likeminded colleagues
Significantly higher number of annual leave than other companies
cons: Difficult to progress in the organisation - few jobs available and lots of talented people you are competing against, who generally have 20+ years more experience than you

pros: open, good people, in most posts you can convince yourself you are doing something positive in the world in creating relationships and dialogue where it would otherwise be difficult.
cons: constant cuts and restructuring, you may have to apply for your own job

review_title: immature processes across HR and finance in particular
pros: Nice people but one or two bad eggs.
cons:
Over worked. Weak performance management across operations. Poor processes and weak management. Susceptible to fraud, nepotism, bullying (London office). 
Too many square pegs in round holes.

review_title: Not recommended if you want to advanced in your career
pros:
Holidays -32 days
Flexible working
Training
Travel
good location
cons:
Organization behaviour
No opportuntities to grow
Bad/ Poor management
No money
People do more than it JD says
Don't value their personnel

pros:
Good home work life
Calm relaxed environment
Good training
cons:
Poor leadership in senior management 
Senior management are bullies
Nasty office politics

pros: The workforce is diverse and everyone who works there tends to support the British Council's mission. It also provides flexible working, great annual leave allowance, casual working environment, and the ability to work from home as much as you like.
cons: Salaries are low, there is lack of progression and forward thinking, and a very risk averse culture.

pros: Staff passionate about the organisation: Good work life balance:Very flexible working patterns:Great location.You are trusted to  manage your time.
cons: There is an unwillingness to promote from within but rather to take on external candidates who demand higher salaries! There seems to be an inequitable work allocation.

review_title: Great work/life balance. Poor leadership & understanding.
pros: Great work/life balanace. Some very skilled individuals to work amongst. Incredibly friendly people to work with.
cons: Lack of strong leadership and knowledge within specific departments. Underpaid with regards to market rates. Little chance of improving initial salary.

pros:
Interesting projects to work on.
Friendly and modern environment.
Great incentive package.
Opportunity to travel
cons:
The experience depends fully on your line manager
Sometimes demotivated employees 
Comparably low salaries in the sector
Rigid and hierarchical, missing drive

pros:
A useful waystage organisation for young aspiring career-minded professionals interested in NGO sector.
Some great colleagues / peers.
cons:
Expect a huge gap between espoused and lived values / behaviours.
Those in senior leadership positions tend to serve themselves and their careers ahead of the corporate mission.

pros: The application process is lengthy but straightforward. You are certain of the dates of your placement in advance, which is helpful.
cons: Twelve hours a week as a Languages Assistant is not a lot, so for those willing to work more, it would be helpful to offer more hours,

pros: Opportunity to work overseas for some people
cons: Poorly run by the executive board leading to massive stress amongst employees. No clear focus as an organisation and every dept doing their own thing. Most staff were really unhappy and unmotivated, and not listened to by directors. Utterly miserable place to work, with minimal chance of expanding your skills.

review_title: Positive work environment, opportunities for career development and rewarding projects
job_title: Project Manager in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: I thoroughly enjoyed my time working at British Council in the Northern Ireland office. A great team of people who are passionate about what they do.
cons: There were a few challenges around availability of permanent versus fixed term contracts

job_title: Graduate Student in Barnsley, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Good HR support whilst in chosen country as a Language Assistant, with a range of locations around the world to choose from.
cons: In Mexico City there were issues with the timing of payments, however the fault laid with the Mexican government by all accounts.

review_title: Not a wonderful organisation; an organisation that does wonderful things
pros: The local staff in every country I've worked in; the kinds of projects we deliver in 110 countries round the world.
cons: Senior management are incompetent, completely unaccountable to anyone for anything, and refuse ever to admit they make mistakes.

review_title: A good place to work for a few years, great opportunities to travel
pros: Friendly staffroom, good colleagues and students
cons: Salaries not in line with rising cost of living. Settling in period is a little rushed

review_title: Good in all departments except pay
pros: Great pension, holidays, benefits and very understanding and flexible as an employer.
cons: Poor pay for level of expertise required and very few rises once in the company

pros: People are friendly.  Opportunity to travel.  Good work life balance.  Great benefits
cons: Consultants get paid ridiculous amounts while permanent staff have been on a pay freeze for years.  Very slow to change.

pros:
Truly excellent people - bright, skilled, with an international outlook.
Amazing brand
Global >100 countries
cons:
Decision-making and commercial thinking weak.
Trying to be all things to all people, with internal silos as a result.

pros: The environment is fun, nice people and get subsidized transport to work.
cons: Standing up for long period of time. Must start at 7-8 in the morning. Long shifts (11-12 hrs). Work only Saturday (or when they have test sessions)

pros: Fantastic experience to work and learn in a large multi-cultural, multi location organisation
cons: Often confused and perpetually changing to stand still

pros: Opportunity to work from home
cons: Bureaucracy, inefficiency, incompetence, politics, old fashioned hierarchy

pros: Place seems to attract good people who work hard. never felt as though someone wasn't pulling their weight. Very refreshing in office environment
cons: Virtually everyone on temp contracts (even managers) so security is hard to acheive

review_title: Interesting, but rapidly needs to catch up with analogue organisations
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Manchester, England
pros: Very diverse, working with people across the world, multiple career paths within
cons: Very large, anonymous, cold at times.  Lacks a focus or purpose at times

pros: Organisation  needed in keeping the kitchen clean and tidy.   working as part of a team.
cons: Not enough over time work

review_title: Interesting organisation with no clear direction
pros: Friendly colleagues  and great values
Standardized hierarchy procedures throughout centre.
cons:
Limited contract (not family friendly).
Change in managment too often.
Non-Standardized Terms And Conditions Of Service (TACOS).
Rigid dependancy on DELTA (or DipTESOL) as a qualification for career progression.

pros: Camaraderie, easy going lovely to work with people.
cons: The sanctions for not delivering is non existent. So everyone talks about budget, and forecasting, no one talks about the actuals!

pros:
short work hours
pay was relatively good for how long you work
the job can be very rewarding if you're placed at a good school
cons:
pay was 2 months late
no training

pros: Good company culture, nice pay, good opportunity to learn
cons: comparably soft in business driven, Top leadership lack of business strategy

review_title: It is all about your team
job_title: Strategic Partnerships Manager in London, England
pros: The people & the context within which the BC works is very interesting.
cons: Highly politicised environment which can make traction difficult for new staff.

pros: Job security and friendly atmosphere
cons: Outdated hierarchical management structure, lack of technical innovation, lack of effective processes and procedures, low salary

pros: Working with like-minded people, on interesting, rewarding projects. Lots of flexibility with working hours and location.
cons: Low salaries compared with level of responsibility
